{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3324485,"name":"","username":"manso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/e99b99/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-05T16:03:17.021Z","cooked":"

Our team bought some RGB LED light strips from AndyMark, for decorative purposes on our robot.

However, we are unsure of how to wire it, we know that it takes 12V input, and I’m also not sure how to program the lights.

I’m assuming that I need some RGB controller like CANLight or REV Blinkin otherwise, I can’t program it. Is it possible to do it with the RoboRIO instead?

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Addressable LEDs

LED strips have been commonly used by teams for several years for a variety of reasons. They allow teams to debug robot functionality from the audience, provide a visual marker for their robot, and...

It says in the description that the strip is not individually addressable.

I answered a similar question about non-addressable LEDs here:

LED strip Java
An important distinction to make is that the one wire with ARGB LEDS is a signal wire and can come directly from the RoboRIO, however with “dumb” RGB strips those 3 wires are the actual power wires supplying the LEDs which cannot be fed directly from the RoboRIO. What you need at a minimum is an LED amplifier such as this: https://a.co/d/90vfAKD Then in code it should be as simple as setting the R, G, and B ports to output the desired duty cycle.
